instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, with a burnt <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>, and I have no other equal board to use other one. Only have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A boards...

Can I use one from any other board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Why would you want to solder FDMF6808N?
Didn't read many threads on the forum about its problems???
Get FDMF6708/3030 from reliable store; avoid any chinese seller!

First be sure CPU core power rail is not shorted to ground.
High chance <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> killed CPU.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: OK. Tks. Better to use FDMF6708.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.0018 in diode reading
I've replaced <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> with a new FDMF6708, but I have no power. It pulls 0.24A from bench PSU, but no power.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Resistance to ground looks good.
But this doesn't mean CPU was not damaged...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi, 
In the morning the behavior was a bit different.
It puls 0.284 A in bench PSU, and i get 0.670V on L7310, but still no power on and no fan spin.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Power on YES, if you got even CPU core voltage.
Don't make confusion between boot and power on!

What is the CPU core behavior, drops to 0.67V from higer voltage (after 5-10s)?
Did you check USB activity?

threads.message:
Hi,
on   <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  it only has 0.68V from start. I starts and stays steady with 0.68V

threads.message: Compare coils voltage with good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I suspect bad CPU, damaged by overvoltage...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

I don't know if it is better opening a new thread...

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board, with similar original problem. <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> was shorted.

After read various threads, i  know i shouldn't use FDMF6808N from Aliexpress.
But just in case, and because i don't have the other IC versions, i replaced <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> with one IC i bough on Aliexpress. Now fans are spinning, but no image and all 3 cpu phase are at 1.7V steady.

Caps lock doesn't turn on a green light, so i suppose, no CPU activity. And like we talked about yesterday in the other thread, cpu core should drop to 0.6V .

So, this could mean CPU damaged by shorted <CHIP>U7320</CHIP>? Or should i try with 3 new FDMF3030?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
The CPU core drop doesn't apply here; only valid for newer machines.
Very likely damaged CPU.

Please, open new thread when needed...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Yes, i should started a new thread. Sorry!

Thanks!
